Pick Algorithm  
Dijkstras is the simplest of the sorting algorithms. It will visit each node in the order in which they are found to be adjacent to the already visited. Dijkstras algorithm is seen as a standard in pathfinding, but can be slow with larger areas to scan. This algorithm does guarantee the shortest path.
A* is an algorithm that looks at number of steps taken, and the euclidean distance from the current cell to the destination. It creates a value from the sum of these two factors that it refers to as f. A* Does guarantee the shortest path and is often credited as the most efficent way to do so.
Greedy is an algorithm that looks at number of steps taken, and the euclidean distance from the current cell to the destination. Like A*, it creates a value from the sum of these two factors that it refers to as f. However the distance is highly prioritized over the steps taken, causing the algorithm to lurch forward "greedily". Greedy does NOT guarantee the shortest path.
Depth First Search is an algorithm that always chooses a new neighbor as opposed to those which have waiting in the queue to be visited. It does not take into account where the end node is and will meander until it stumbles across it. As the visualizer will show, this algorithm, while useful in other applications, is not optimal for pathfinding and does NOT guarantee the shortest path.
